byline.contributor: Dave Caldwell contributed reporting. Viv Bernstein contributed reporting from Concord, N.C.

abstract: Many insiders suggest that the IndyCar crash that killed driver Dan Wheldon resulted from recipe for disaster waiting to happen; start with problematic layout of Las Vegas Motor Speedway that drivers say is better suited to stock car racing, mix in a field of expert drivers with rookies and rusty ones, put millions of dollars on the line and then add speed; Wheldon, who had barely raced in 2011, was offered $2.5 million bonus for dangerous stunt of starting at back and threading through slower, less-experienced drivers to win.
snippet: On Sunday, the mix of a fast track packed with drivers with millions of dollars on the line led to one of Indy car’s worst crashes and the death of the driver Dan Wheldon.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, the mix of a fast track packed with drivers with millions of dollars on the line led to one of Indy car’s worst crashes and the death of the driver Dan Wheldon.
